member.summary: The AnchorArea class is used to specify the anchor properties of an object. You can set to align the content to the left, right, top or bottom using the relative properties (Left, Right, Top, Bottom). member.name: T:DevAge.Drawing.RectangleBorder
member.summary: A struct that represents the borders of a cell. Contains 4 borders: Right, Left, Top, Bottom. If you have 2 adjacent cells and want to create a 1 pixel width border, you must set width 1 for one cell and width 0 for the other. Usually a cell has only Right and Bottom border. The bottom and top border lines are drawed over the right and left lines.

member.name: P:DevAge.Drawing.VisualElements.BackgroundLinearGradient.BlendFactors
member.summary:
Gradients are commonly used to smoothly shade the interiors of shapes. A blend pattern is defined by two arrays (Factors and Positions) that each contain the same number of elements. Each element of the Positions array represents a proportion of the distance along the gradient line. Each element of the Factors array represents the proportion of the starting and ending colors in the gradient blend at the position along the gradient line represented by the corresponding element in the Positions array. For example, if corresponding elements of the Positions and Factors arrays are 0.2 and 0.3, respectively, for a linear gradient from blue to red along a 100-pixel line, the color 20 pixels along that line (20 percent of the distance) consists of 30 percent blue and 70 percent red.
See System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Blend for details

member.name: P:DevAge.Drawing.VisualElements.BackgroundLinearGradient.BlendPositions
member.summary:
Gradients are commonly used to smoothly shade the interiors of shapes. A blend pattern is defined by two arrays (Factors and Positions) that each contain the same number of elements. Each element of the Positions array represents a proportion of the distance along the gradient line. Each element of the Factors array represents the proportion of the starting and ending colors in the gradient blend at the position along the gradient line represented by the corresponding element in the Positions array. For example, if corresponding elements of the Positions and Factors arrays are 0.2 and 0.3, respectively, for a linear gradient from blue to red along a 100-pixel line, the color 20 pixels along that line (20 percent of the distance) consists of 30 percent blue and 70 percent red.
See System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Blend for details

member.name: M:DevAge.Windows.Forms.DevAgeRichTextBox.BeginUpdate
member.summary: Maintains performance while updating.

remarks.para: It is recommended to call this method before doing any major updates that you do not wish the user to see. Remember to call EndUpdate when you are finished with the update. Nested calls are supported.
Calling this method will prevent redrawing. It will also setup the event mask of the underlying richedit control so that no events are sent.

member.name: M:DevAge.Windows.Forms.DevAgeRichTextBox.EndUpdate
member.summary: Resumes drawing and event handling.
member.remarks: This method should be called every time a call is made made to BeginUpdate. It resets the event mask to it's original value and enables redrawing of the control.

member.name: T:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator
member.summary: An interface to support value conversion and validation. Naming Legend: Object = an object not yet converted for the current validator, Value = an object already converted and valid for the current validator, String = a string that can be used for conversion to and from Value, DisplayString = a string representation of the Value

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.IsNullString(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the string is null or if is equals to the NullString

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.ObjectToValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Convert an object according to the current ValueType of the validator

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.ValueToObject(System.Object,System.Type)
member.summary: Convert a value valid for the current validator ValueType to an object with the Type specified. Throw an exception on error.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.ValueToString(System.Object)
member.summary: Convert a value valid for the current validator ValueType to a string that can be used for other conversions, for example StringToValue method.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.StringToValue(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to an object according to the type of the string editor

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.IsStringConversionSupported
member.summary: Returns true if string conversion is suported. AllowStringConversion must be true and the current Validator must support string conversion.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.ValueToDisplayString(System.Object)
member.summary: Converts a value valid for this validator valuetype to a string representation. The string cannot be used for conversion. If the validator support string conversion this method simply call ValueToString otherwise call Value.ToString()

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.IsValidValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns true if the value is valid for this type of editor without any conversion.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.IsValidObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns true if the object is valid for this type of validator, using conversion functions.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.IsValidObject(System.Object,System.Object@)
member.summary: Returns true if the object is valid for this type of validator, using conversion functions. Returns as parameter the value converted.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.IsValidString(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the string is valid for this type of editor, using string conversion function.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.IsValidString(System.String,System.Object@)
member.summary: Returns true if the string is valid for this type of editor, using string conversion function. An returns the object converted.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.IsInStandardValues(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns true if the value specified is presents in the list StandardValues.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.StandardValueAtIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the standard values at the specified index. If StandardValues support IList use simple the indexer method otherwise loop troght the collection.

member.name: M:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.StandardValuesIndexOf(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the index of the specified standard value. -1 if not found. If StandardValues support IList use simple the indexer method otherwise loop troght the collection.

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.AllowNull
member.summary: True to allow null object value or NullString string Value

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.NullString
member.summary: Null string representation. A string is null when is null or when is equals to this string. Default is empty string. Used by ValueToString and StringToValue

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.NullDisplayString
member.summary: Null string representation. A string is null when is null or when is equals to this string. Default is empty string. Used by ValueToDisplayString

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.AllowStringConversion
member.summary: Gets or Sets if the string conversion is allowed.

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.MinimumValue
member.summary: Minimum value allowed. If null no check is performed. The value must derive from IComparable interface to use Minimum or Maximum feature.

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.MaximumValue
member.summary: Maximum value allowed. If null no check is performed. The value must derive from IComparable interface to use Minimum or Maximum feature.

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.ValueType
member.summary: Type allowed for the current editor. Cannot be null.

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.DefaultValue
member.summary: Default value for this editor, usually is the default value for the specified type.

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.StandardValues
member.summary: A list of values that this editor can support. If StandardValuesExclusive is true then the editor can only support one of these values.

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.StandardValuesExclusive
member.summary: If StandardValuesExclusive is true then the editor can only support the list specified in StandardValues.

member.name: P:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.CultureInfo
member.summary: Culture for conversion. If null the default user culture is used. Default is null.

member.name: E:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.ConvertingObjectToValue
member.summary: Fired when converting a object to the value specified. Called from method ObjectToValue and IsValidObject

member.name: E:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.IValidator.ConvertingValueToObject
member.summary: Fired when converting a object to the value specified. Called from method ObjectToValue and IsValidObject

member.name: T:DevAge.ComponentModel.Validator.ValidatorBase
member.summary: A base class to support value conversion and validation. This class is used if no conversion is required or as a base class for specialized validator. Naming Legend: Object = an object not yet converted for the current validator, Value = an object already converted and valid for the current validator, String = a string that can be used for conversion to and from Value, DisplayString = a string representation of the Value

member.name: T:DevAge.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommandBuilder
member.summary: This class is similar to the System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommandBuilder, but use only the DataTable to create the required commands. Don't support identity (autoincrement) column and only the base data type. This class don't use the data source to explore the data but only the DataTable informations. So you must populate the PrimaryKeys of the DataSet. I suggest to use GUID column (uniqueidentifier) to replace the identity column. Remember to set the Connection of the generated command.

member.summary: Invalidate the cells

member.name: M:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.RangeToCellRange(SourceGrid.Range)
member.summary: This method converts a Position to the real range of the cell. This is usefull when RowSpan or ColumnSpan is greater than 1. For example suppose to have at grid[0,0] a cell with ColumnSpan equal to 2. If you call this method with the position 0,0 returns 0,0-0,1 and if you call this method with 0,1 return again 0,0-0,1.

member.name: M:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.PositionToStartPosition(SourceGrid.Position)
member.summary: This method converts a Position to the real start position of cell. This is usefull when RowSpan or ColumnSPan is greater than 1. For example suppose to have at grid[0,0] a cell with ColumnSpan equal to 2. If you call this method with the position 0,0 returns 0,0 and if you call this method with 0,1 return again 0,0. Get the real position for the specified position. For example when p_Position is a merged cell this method returns the starting position of the merged cells. Usually this method returns the same cell specified as parameter. This method is used for processing arrow keys, to find a valid cell when the focus is in a merged cell. For this class returns always p_Position.

member.name: M:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.PositionToCellRange(SourceGrid.Position)
member.summary: This method converts a Position to the real range of the cell. This is usefull when RowSpan or ColumnSpan is greater than 1. For example suppose to have at grid[0,0] a cell with ColumnSpan equal to 2. If you call this method with the position 0,0 returns 0,0-0,1 and if you call this method with 0,1 return again 0,0-0,1.

member.name: M:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.Focus(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set the Focus on the grid with an optional behaviour. If selectFirstCell is true and the FocusStyle is equal to FocusStyle.FocusFirstCellOnEnter then if there isn't a cell selected the first cell of the grid receive became the active cell. Otherwise the focus is not changed. The Default is true.

member.summary: Gets or sets the selection mode. Changing this property cause the Selection object to be recreated, for this reason remember to set this property at the beginning of your code.

member.name: P:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.MouseDownPosition
member.summary: Represents the cell that have received the MouseDown event. You can use this cell for contextmenu logic. Can be null.

member.name: P:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.MouseCellPosition
member.summary: The cell position currently under the mouse cursor (row, col). If you MouseDown on a cell this cell is the MouseCellPosition until an MouseUp is fired

member.name: P:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.MouseSelectionRange
member.summary: Returns the cells that are selected with the mouse. Range.Empty if no cells are selected. Consider that this method returns valid cells only during the mouse down operations, when release the mouse the cells are selected and you can read them using Grid.Selection object.

member.name: P:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.OverrideCommonCmdKey
member.summary: True to override with the ProcessCmdKey the common Command Key: Enter, Escape, Tab

member.name: P:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.SpecialKeys
member.summary: Special keys that the grid can handle. You can change this enum to block or allow some special keys function. For example to disable Ctrl+C Copy operation remove from this enum the GridSpecialKeys.Ctrl_C.

member.name: P:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.AcceptsInputChar
member.summary: True accepts input char when the grid has the focus. Used for example to start the edit operation without processing the char. If you set this property to false when the character is sended to the windows forms handler and can be used for example to execute directly some access key (shortcut keys). Default is true.

member.name: P:SourceGrid.GridVirtual.LinkedControls
member.summary: List of controls that are linked to a specific cell position. For example is used for editors controls. Key=Control, Value=Position. The controls are automatically removed from the list when they are removed from the Grid.Controls collection

member.name: T:SourceGrid.Cells.CellControl
member.summary: The CellControl class is used to create a cell with a Windows Forms Control inside. The CellControl class requires a new Windows Forms control for each cell. Unfortunately Winwods Forms control requires a lot of system resources and with many cells this can cause system fault or out of memory conditions. Basically I suggest to use CellControl with no more than 50 cells and only if necessary, usually it is better to use standard cells. Another problem with the CellControl class is that it is not integrated well with the rest of the grid (control borders, cell navigation, ...) Finally a cell of type CellControl cannot be moved, for example you cannot use sort, move the columns, ... when using a CellControl.

member.name: T:SourceGrid.Cells.Controllers.Button
member.summary: Button controller is used to executed a specific action when the user click on a cell or when the user press the Enter or Space key (using the OnKeyDown event). Is normally used with the Link or Button Cell. Override the OnExecuted to add your code or use the Executed event.

member.name: F:SourceGrid.Cells.Controllers.Button.mLastButton
member.summary:
I mantain the last mouse button pressed here to simulate exactly the behavior of the standard system button.
Here are the events executed on a system button:
[status checked = false] MouseDown [status checked = false] CheckedChanged [status checked = true] Click [status checked = true] MouseUp [status checked = true]
Consider that I can use this member varialbes because also if you have multiple grid or multiple threads there is only one mouse that can fire the events. Consider also that I cannot use the Click event because in that event I don't have informations about the button pressed.

Allow null

UITypeEditor if null must be populated the TypeConverter

member.summary: Don't draw a border around each selection range

member.summary: Draw a border around the range that contains the focus.

member.name: F:SourceGrid.SelectionBorderMode.FocusCell
member.summary: Draw a border around the focusl cell

member.name: F:SourceGrid.SelectionBorderMode.UniqueRange
member.summary: Draw a border around the selection range only is there is only one range selected

member.summary: Like the UniqueRange enum but when there is more then one range set the range only on the FocusCell

member.name: T:SourceGrid.SelectionMaskStyle
member.summary: SelectionmaskStyle, used to customize the visual style of the selection mask. (Flags)

member.name: F:SourceGrid.SelectionMaskStyle.None
member.summary: None. No special flags

member.name: F:SourceGrid.SelectionMaskStyle.DrawOnlyInitializedCells
member.summary: Used to draw only initialized cells. If you have uninitialized cell (you don't create a cell for a specific position: grid[0,0] = null;) the selection mask is not drawed on this cell. Consider that with this flags the drawing method is more complex and slow.If you use this flag the border can only be set to FocusCell or None.

member.name: F:SourceGrid.SelectionMaskStyle.DrawSeletionOverCells
member.summary: Used to draw the selection over the the cells, usually used with a transparent backcolor drawed over the normal cell. If not set, each cells (View) draw the selection or focus backcolor inside the normal drawing code.

member.name: F:SourceGrid.SelectionMaskStyle.Default
member.summary: Default value: None

member.name: M:SourceGrid.IHiddenRowCoordinator.LoopVisibleRows(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a sequence of row indexes which are visible only. Correctly handles invisible rows.
member.param: How many visible rows to return
member.returns: Can return less rows than requested. This might occur if you request to return visible rows in the end of the grid, and all the rows would be hidden. In that case no indexes would be returned at all, even though specific amount of rows was requested

member.name: M:SourceGrid.IHiddenRowCoordinator.ConvertScrollbarValueToRowIndex(System.Int32)
member.param: The value of the vertical scroll bar. Note that this does not directly relate to row number. If there are no hidden rows at all, then scroll bar value directly relates to row index number. However, if some rows are hidden, then this value is different. Basically, it says how many visible rows must be scrolled down

member.name: M:SourceGrid.StandardHiddenRowCoordinator.LoopVisibleRows(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a sequence of row indexes which are visible only. Correctly handles invisible rows.
member.param: The value of the vertical scroll bar. Note that this does not directly relate to row number. If there are no hidden rows at all, then scroll bar value directly relates to row index number. However, if some rows are hidden, then this value is different. Basically, it says how many visible rows must be scrolled down
How many visible rows to return
member.returns: Can return less rows than requested. This might occur if you request to return visible rows in the end of the grid, and all the rows would be hidden. In that case no indexes would be returned at all, even though specific amount of rows was requested

member.name: P:SourceGrid.Grid.AllowOverlappingCells
member.summary: Indicates that overlapping cells are not allowed and will be thrown an exception. This is needed due to the fact that when there are two overlapping spanned cells, SourceGrid can not reliably draw them, since the call to function GetCell(x,y) returns random results. However, some users epxressed the need to allow such behaviour. So this flag forces Grid to not check for overlapping cells

In the future it would be nice to reduce it so that separate implementations would be possible

This interface helps work with spanned ranges collection
There are two implementations at the moment. One is SpannedRangesList, another is QuadTree implementation, which is much faster. Look at unit tests for speed comparisons: TestSpannedCellRnages_Performance: TestBoth.

member.name: T:QuadTreeLib.QuadTree
member.summary: A Quadtree is a structure designed to partition space so that it's faster to find out what is inside or outside a given area. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadtree This QuadTree contains items that have an area (RectangleF) it will store a reference to the item in the quad that is just big enough to hold it. Each quad has a bucket that contain multiple items.

member.name: T:SourceGrid.QuadTreeRangesList
member.summary:
This is a QuadTree implementation for cell ranges. Performance is definetely not O(n*n) as in simple list of ranges
Have a look at these numbers to see the difference:
with simple List of Ranges Total 30000 spanned ranges Total result count 90000 Total time 98541 ms Average time 0,98541 Total queries 100000
testing quad tree Total 30000 spanned ranges Total result count 90000 Total time 1495 ms Average time 0,01495 Total queries 100000 max tree depth: 11

member.name: M:QuadTreeLib.IQuadTreeNodeDivider.CreateNewRoot(QuadTreeLib.QuadTreeNode)
member.summary: Expand tree by creating new root. Add old root under new root, and create any additional tree nodes that are needed

member.name: T:QuadTreeLib.ProportioanteSizeNodeDivider
member.summary:
Tries to divide into nodes, that are more suited for grids, which expand more into rows than into columns. In this case, quad tree does not end up divided into regions where width is very very small.
This is much more efficien space partitioning

member.name: T:QuadTreeLib.HalfSizeNodeDivider
member.summary:
Creates sub-nodes simply by dividing current node by 2 and creating 4 smaller regions.
This is not efficient if the area is very rectangular, for example, row count 10 000 and column count 10
Use ProportioanteSizeNodeDivider instead

member.summary: Move the active cell (focus), moving the row and column as specified. Try to set the focus using the first shift, if failed try to use the second shift (rowShift2, colShift2). If rowShift2 or colShift2 is int.MaxValue the next start position is the maximum row or column, if is int.MinValue 0 is used, otherwise the current position is shifted using the specified value. This method is usually used for the Tab navigation using this code : MoveActiveCell(0,1,1,0); Returns true if the focus can be moved. Returns false if there aren't any cell to move.

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.IGridSelection.MoveActiveCell(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Move the active cell (focus), moving the row and column as specified. Returns true if the focus can be moved. Returns false if there aren't any cell to move. Does reset selection

member.name: T:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByCells
member.summary:
Similar to , this class merge adjancent ranges if they are differ only by row or column count.
See TestRangeMergerByCells for unit tests, which show how this class works

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByCells.JoinAdjancedRecursive
member.summary: Repeat this function until it returns false to recursively merge all ranges
member.returns: true, if at least two ranges were joined into single

member.summary: A selection class that support free selection of cells (ranges)

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.FreeSelection.IsEmpty
member.summary: Returns true if the selection is empty

member.summary: Returns the selected region.

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.FreeSelection.IntersectsWith(SourceGrid.Range)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified selection intersect with the range

member.name: T:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows
member.summary:
Contains a list of ranges which differ only by row, that is vertically. This the reason why the class contains a word "row" in its name.
"Merger" means that it will merge adjancent ranges into single big range. So, for example, if you have 100 ranges from first row to second, that equals to one big range from row 1 to 100. If Row 50 is not selected, then this class splits one big range into two smaller. One from first row to row number 49, and anoter range from row 51 to row 100
Although some functions work with Range structure, which has also a horizontal span, that information is actually not needed, and used as dummy only.

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows.LoopAllRanges
member.summary: Loops via all ranges. Ranges are guaranteed to be ordered from lowest row to highest.

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows.GetSelectedRowRegions(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a list of selected ranges
member.param: start column, usually 0
end column, usually equals to column count - 1

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows.MergeRecursive(SourceGrid.Range)
member.summary: Merges given range with one of the intersecting range in m_ranges if no intersecting ranges is found, then rangeToMerge is added to m_ranges

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows.JoinAjdancedRecursive
member.summary: Returns true if at least two ranges were joined

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows.AddRange(SourceGrid.Range)
member.summary: Add a range to collection. If the range can be added (merged) to existing range, it will be added so. This will guarantee that the number of different ranges is kept to minimal. In theory only if user selects every second row, this would produce RowCount / 2 number of ranges. In practice, there are rarely more than 3 - 5 different selection regions
member.param: columns values are ignored, so simply put 0 as start colum and 1 as end column. Only row values matter

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows.MergeByRow(SourceGrid.Range,SourceGrid.Range)
member.summary: Returns new range witch is the max of both ranges in row axis

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows.RemoveRange(SourceGrid.Range)
member.summary:
As opposed to Adding a range, this will remove a range. It might happend that removing a range is dividing one bigger range into two smaller ones. So practically the number of ranges might increase.
It might be that this method might carry more exact meaning with "Exclude", instead of "RemoveRange"

member.name: M:SourceGrid.Selection.RangeMergerByRows.GetRowsIndex
member.summary: Returns a list of indexes of rows

member.name: T:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView
member.summary: An ObjectListView is a much easier to use, and much more powerful, version of the ListView.

remarks.para: An ObjectListView automatically populates a ListView control with information taken from a given collection of objects. It can do this because each column is configured to know which bit of the model object (the "aspect") it should be displaying. Columns similarly understand how to sort the list based on their aspect, and how to construct groups using their aspect.

Aspects are extracted by giving the name of a method to be called or a property to be fetched. These names can be simple names or they can be dotted to chain property access e.g. "Owner.Address.Postcode". Aspects can also be extracted by installing a delegate.
An ObjectListView can show a "this list is empty" message when there is nothing to show in the list, so that the user knows the control is supposed to be empty.

Right clicking on a column header should present a menu which can contain: commands (sort, group, ungroup); filtering; and column selection. Whether these parts of the menu appear is controlled by ShowCommandMenuOnRightClick, ShowFilterMenuOnRightClick and SelectColumnsOnRightClick respectively.

The groups created by an ObjectListView can be configured to include other formatting information, including a group icon, subtitle and task button. Using some undocumented interfaces, these groups can even on virtual lists.

ObjectListView supports dragging rows to other places, including other application. Special support is provide for drops from other ObjectListViews in the same application. In many cases, an ObjectListView becomes a full drag source by setting to true. Similarly, to accept drops, it is usually enough to set to true, and then handle the and events (or the and events, if you only want to handle drops from other ObjectListViews in your application).
For these classes to build correctly, the project must have references to these assemblies:

item.description: System
System.Data
System.Design
System.Drawing
System.Windows.Forms (obviously)

member.summary: Convert the given enumerable into an ArrayList as efficiently as possible

If true, this method will always create a new collection.

remarks.para: When we move to .NET 3.5, we can use LINQ and not need this method.

member.name: M:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.AddObjects(System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Add the given collection of model objects to this control.
member.param: A collection of model objects

remarks.para: The added objects will appear in their correct sort position, if sorting is active (i.e. if LastSortColumn is not null). Otherwise, they will appear at the end of the list.
No check is performed to see if any of the objects are already in the ListView.
Null objects are silently ignored.

member.summary: Organise the view items into groups, based on the given column

remarks.para: If the AlwaysGroupByColumn property is not null, the list view items will be organisd by that column, and the 'column' parameter will be ignored.
This method triggers sorting events: BeforeSorting and AfterSorting.

member.param: The column whose values should be used for sorting.

member.name: M:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.BuildGroups(BrightIdeasSoftware.OLVColumn,System.Windows.Forms.SortOrder,BrightIdeasSoftware.OLVColumn,System.Windows.Forms.SortOrder,BrightIdeasSoftware.OLVColumn,System.Windows.Forms.SortOrder)
member.summary: Organise the view items into groups, based on the given columns
member.param: What column will be used for grouping
What ordering will be used for groups
The column whose values should be used for sorting. Cannot be null
The order in which the values from column will be sorted
When the values from 'column' are equal, use the values provided by this column
How will the secondary values be sorted
member.remarks: This method does not trigger sorting events. Use BuildGroups() to do that

remarks.para: Use this method in situations were the contents of the list is basically the same as previously.

member.name: M:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ApplyExtendedStyles
member.summary: Apply all required extended styles to our control.

remarks.para: Whenever .NET code sets an extended style, it erases all other extended styles that it doesn't use. So, we have to explicit reapply the styles that we have added.

Normally, we would override CreateParms property and update the ExStyle member, but ListView seems to ignore all ExStyles that it doesn't already know about. Worse, when we set the LVS_EX_HEADERINALLVIEWS value, bad things happen (the control crashes!).

member.summary: Copy a text and html representation of the selected rows onto the clipboard.
member.remarks: Be careful when using this with virtual lists. If the user has selected 10,000,000 rows, this method will faithfully try to copy all of them to the clipboard. From the user's point of view, your program will appear to have hung.

member.name: M:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SetNativeBackgroundWatermark(System.Drawing.Image)
member.summary: Set the given image to be fixed in the bottom right of the list view. This image will not scroll when the list view scrolls.

remarks.para: This method uses ListView's native ability to display a background image. It has a few limitations:

item.description: It doesn't work well with owner drawn mode. In owner drawn mode, each cell draws itself, including its background, which covers the background image.
It doesn't look very good when grid lines are enabled, since the grid lines are drawn over the image.
It does not work at all on XP.
Obviously, it doesn't look good when alternate row background colors are enabled.

remarks.para: If you can live with these limitations, native watermarks are quite neat. They are true backgrounds, not translucent overlays like the OverlayImage uses. They also have the decided advantage over overlays in that they work correctly even in MDI applications.
Setting this clears any background image.

member.param: The image to be drawn. If null, any existing image will be removed.

member.name: M:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SetNativeBackgroundImage(System.Drawing.Image,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the given image to be background of the ListView so that it appears at the given percentage offsets within the list.

remarks.para: This has the same limitations as described in . Make sure those limitations are understood before using the method.

This is very similar to setting the property of the standard .NET ListView, except that the standard BackgroundImage does not handle images with transparent areas properly -- it renders transparent areas as black. This method does not have that problem.
Setting this clears any background watermark.

member.param: The image to be drawn. If null, any existing image will be removed.
The horizontal percentage where the image will be placed. 0 is absolute left, 100 is absolute right.
The vertical percentage where the image will be placed.

member.name: M:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SetNativeBackgroundTiledImage(System.Drawing.Image)
member.summary: Set the given image to be the tiled background of the ListView.

remarks.para: This has the same limitations as described in and . Make sure those limitations are understood before using the method.

member.param: The image to be drawn. If null, any existing image will be removed.

member.name: M:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SaveState
member.summary: Return a byte array that represents the current state of the ObjectListView, such that the state can be restored by RestoreState()

remarks.para:
The state of an ObjectListView includes the attributes that the user can modify:
current view (i.e. Details, Tile, Large Icon...)
sort column and direction
column order
column widths
column visibility
It does not include selection or the scroll position.

member.returns: A byte array representing the state of the ObjectListView

member.name: M:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.RestoreState(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Restore the state of the control from the given string, which must have been produced by SaveState()
member.param: A byte array returned from SaveState()
member.returns: Returns true if the state was restored

member.remarks: We cannot rely on lvi.Index in this method. In a straight list, lvi.Index is the display index, and can be used to determine whether the row should be colored. But when organised by groups, lvi.Index is not useable because it still refers to the position in the overall list, not the display order.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.IgnoreMissingAspects
member.summary: Gets or sets whether all ObjectListViews will silently ignore missing aspect errors.

remarks.para: By default, if an ObjectListView is asked to display an aspect (i.e. a field/property/method) that does not exist from a model, it displays an error message in that cell, since that condition is normally a programming error. There are some use cases where this is not an error -- in those cases, set this to true and ObjectListView will simply display an empty cell.
Be warned: if you set this to true, it can be very difficult to track down typing mistakes or name changes in AspectNames.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowCellPaddingBounds
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the control will draw a rectangle in each cell showing the cell padding.

remarks.para: This can help with debugging display problems from cell padding.
As with all cell padding, this setting only takes effect when the control is owner drawn.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.AdditionalFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets an model filter that is combined with any column filtering that the end-user specifies.
member.remarks: This is different from the ModelFilter property, since setting that will replace any column filtering, whereas setting this will combine this filter with the column filtering

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.AllColumns
member.summary: Get or set all the columns that this control knows about. Only those columns where IsVisible is true will be seen by the user.

remarks.para: If you want to add new columns programmatically, add them to AllColumns and then call RebuildColumns(). Normally, you do not have to deal with this property directly. Just use the IDE.
If you do add or remove columns from the AllColumns collection, you have to call RebuildColumns() to make those changes take effect.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.AlwaysGroupBySortOrder

member.remarks: This will obviously be null if no cell is being edited.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CellEditTabChangesRows
member.summary: Gets or sets the behaviour of the Tab key when editing a cell on the left or right edge of the control. If this is false (the default), pressing Tab will wrap to the other side of the same row. If this is true, pressing Tab when editing the right most cell will advance to the next row and Shift-Tab when editing the left-most cell will change to the previous row.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CellEditEnterChangesRows
member.summary: Gets or sets the behaviour of the Enter keys while editing a cell. If this is false (the default), pressing Enter will simply finish the editing operation. If this is true, Enter will finish the edit operation and start a new edit operation on the cell below the current cell, wrapping to the top of the next row when at the bottom cell.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CellToolTip
member.summary: Gets the tool tip control that shows tips for the cells

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CellPadding
member.summary: Gets or sets how many pixels will be left blank around each cell of this item. Cell contents are aligned after padding has been taken into account.

remarks.para: Each value of the given rectangle will be treated as an inset from the corresponding side. The width of the rectangle is the padding for the right cell edge. The height of the rectangle is the padding for the bottom cell edge.

So, this.olv1.CellPadding = new Rectangle(1, 2, 3, 4); will leave one pixel of space to the left of the cell, 2 pixels at the top, 3 pixels of space on the right edge, and 4 pixels of space at the bottom of each cell.
This setting only takes effect when the control is owner drawn.
This setting only affects the contents of the cell. The background is not affected.
If you set this to a foolish value, your control will appear to be empty.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CellVerticalAlignment
member.summary: Gets or sets how cells will be vertically aligned by default.
member.remarks: This setting only takes effect when the control is owner drawn. It will only be noticable when RowHeight has been set such that there is some vertical space in each row.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CheckBoxes
member.summary: Should this list show checkboxes?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CheckedObject
member.summary: Return the model object of the row that is checked or null if no row is checked or more than one row is checked

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CheckedObjects
member.summary: Get or set the collection of model objects that are checked. When setting this property, any row whose model object isn't in the given collection will be unchecked. Setting to null is equivilent to unchecking all.

remarks.para: This property returns a simple collection. Changes made to the returned collection do NOT affect the list. This is different to the behaviour of CheckedIndicies collection.
.NET's CheckedItems property is not helpful. It is just a short-hand for iterating through the list looking for items that are checked.

The performance of the get method is O(n), where n is the number of items in the control. The performance of the set method is O(n + m) where m is the number of objects being checked. Be careful on long lists.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CheckedObjectsEnumerable
member.summary: Gets or sets the checked objects from an enumerable.
member.remarks: Useful for checking all objects in the list.
member.example: this.olv1.CheckedObjectsEnumerable = this.olv1.Objects;

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.Columns
member.summary: Gets Columns for this list. We hide the original so we can associate a specialised editor with it.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ColumnsForTileView
member.summary: Get/set the list of columns that should be used when the list switches to tile view.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ColumnsInDisplayOrder
member.summary: Return the visible columns in the order they are displayed to the user

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ContentRectangle
member.summary: Get the area of the control that shows the list, minus any header control

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CopySelectionOnControlC
member.summary: Gets or sets if the selected rows should be copied to the clipboard when the user presses Ctrl-C

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CopySelectionOnControlCUsesDragSource
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the Control-C copy to clipboard functionality should use the installed DragSource to create the data object that is placed onto the clipboard.
member.remarks: This is normally what is desired, unless a custom DragSource is installed that does some very specialized drag-drop behaviour.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.Decorations
member.summary: Gets the list of decorations that will be drawn the ListView

remarks.para: Do not modify the contents of this list directly. Use the AddDecoration() and RemoveDecoration() methods.
A decoration scrolls with the list contents. An overlay is fixed in place.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.DefaultRenderer
member.summary: When owner drawing, this renderer will draw columns that do not have specific renderer given to them
member.remarks: If you try to set this to null, it will revert to a BaseRenderer

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.DragSource
member.summary: Gets or sets the object that controls how drags start from this control

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.DropSink
member.summary: Gets or sets the object that controls how drops are accepted and processed by this ListView.

remarks.para: If the given sink is an instance of SimpleDropSink, then events from the drop sink will be automatically forwarded to the ObjectListView (which means that handlers for those event can be configured within the IDE).
If this is set to null, the control will not accept drops.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.EmptyListMsg
member.summary: Gets or sets the text that should be shown when there are no items in this list view.
member.remarks: If the EmptyListMsgOverlay has been changed to something other than a TextOverlay, this property does nothing

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.EmptyListMsgFont
member.summary: Gets or sets the font in which the List Empty message should be drawn
member.remarks: If the EmptyListMsgOverlay has been changed to something other than a TextOverlay, this property does nothing

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.EmptyListMsgFontOrDefault
member.summary: Return the font for the 'list empty' message or a reasonable default

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.EmptyListMsgOverlay
member.summary: Gets or sets the overlay responsible for drawing the List Empty msg.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.FilteredObjects
member.summary: Gets the collection of objects that survive any filtering that may be in place.

remarks.para: This collection is the result of filtering the current list of objects. It is not a snapshot of the filtered list that was last used to build the control.
Normal warnings apply when using this with virtual lists. It will work, but it may take a while.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.FilterMenuBuildStrategy
member.summary: Gets or sets the strategy object that will be used to build the Filter menu
member.remarks: If this is null, no filter menu will be built.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.Groups
member.summary: Hide the Groups collection so it's not visible in the Properties grid.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.GroupImageList
member.summary: Gets or sets the image list from which group header will take their images
member.remarks: If this is not set, then group headers will not show any images.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.GroupWithItemCountFormat
member.summary: Gets how the group label should be formatted when a group is empty or contains more than one item
member.remarks:
The given format string must have two placeholders:
{0} - the original group title
{1} - the number of items in the group

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.GroupWithItemCountFormatOrDefault
member.summary: Return this.GroupWithItemCountFormat or a reasonable default

member.summary: Gets how the group label should be formatted when a group contains only a single item
member.remarks:

{1} - the number of items in the group (always 1)

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.GroupWithItemCountSingularFormatOrDefault
member.summary: Gets GroupWithItemCountSingularFormat or a reasonable default

member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not the groups in this ObjectListView should be collapsible.
member.remarks: This feature only works under Vista and later.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HasEmptyListMsg
member.summary: Does this listview have a message that should be drawn when the list is empty?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HasOverlays
member.summary: Get whether there are any overlays to be drawn

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HeaderControl
member.summary: Gets the header control for the ListView

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HeaderFont
member.summary: Gets or sets the font in which the text of the column headers will be drawn
member.remarks: Individual columns can override this through their HeaderFormatStyle property.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HeaderFormatStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the style that will be used to draw the columm headers of the listview

remarks.para: This is only used when HeaderUsesThemes is false.
Individual columns can override this through their HeaderFormatStyle property.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HeaderMaximumHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum height of the header. -1 means no maximum.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HeaderUsesThemes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the header will be drawn strictly according to the OS's theme.

remarks.para: If this is set to true, the header will be rendered completely by the system, without any of ObjectListViews fancy processing -- no images in header, no filter indicators, no word wrapping, no header styling.

If this is set to false, ObjectListView will render the header as it thinks best. If no special features are required, then ObjectListView will delegate rendering to the OS. Otherwise, ObjectListView will draw the header according to the configuration settings.
The effect of not being themed will be different from OS to OS. At very least, the sort indicator will not be standard.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HeaderWordWrap
member.summary: Gets or sets the whether the text in the header will be word wrapped.

remarks.para: Line breaks will be applied between words. Words that are too long will still be ellipsed.
As with all settings that make the header look different, HeaderUsesThemes must be set to false, otherwise the OS will be responsible for drawing the header, and it does not allow word wrapped text.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HeaderToolTip
member.summary: Gets the tool tip that shows tips for the column headers

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HotRowIndex

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HotColumnIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the subitem that the mouse is currently over

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HotCellHitLocationEx
member.summary: Gets an extended indication of the part of item/subitem/group that the mouse is currently over

member.summary: Gets the group that the mouse is over

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HotItemStyle
member.summary: What sort of formatting should be applied to the row under the cursor?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HyperlinkStyle
member.summary: What sort of formatting should be applied to hyperlinks?

member.summary: What color should be used for the background of selected rows?
member.remarks: Windows does not give the option of changing the selection background. So the control has to be owner drawn to see the result of this setting. Setting UseCustomSelectionColors = true will do this for you.

member.summary: What color should be used for the foreground of selected rows?
member.remarks: Windows does not give the option of changing the selection foreground (text color). So the control has to be owner drawn to see the result of this setting. Setting UseCustomSelectionColors = true will do this for you.

member.summary: Return the color should be used for the foreground of selected rows or a reasonable default

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.IncludeHiddenColumnsInDataTransfer
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not hidden columns should be included in the text representation of rows that are copied or dragged to another application. If this is false (the default), only visible columns will be included.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.IncludeColumnHeadersInCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not hidden columns should be included in the text representation of rows that are copied or dragged to another application. If this is false (the default), only visible columns will be included.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.IsCellEditing
member.summary: Return true if a cell edit operation is currently happening

member.summary: Return true if the ObjectListView is being used within the development environment.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.IsFiltering
member.summary: Gets whether or not the current list is filtering its contents

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.IsSearchOnSortColumn
member.summary: When the user types into a list, should the values in the current sort column be searched to find a match? If this is false, the primary column will always be used regardless of the sort column.
member.remarks: When this is true, the behavior is like that of ITunes.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.IsSimpleDropSink
member.summary: Gets or sets if this control will use a SimpleDropSink to receive drops

remarks.para: Setting this replaces any previous DropSink.

After setting this to true, the SimpleDropSink will still need to be configured to say when it can accept drops and what should happen when something is dropped. The need to do these things makes this property mostly useless :(

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.IsSimpleDragSource
member.summary: Gets or sets if this control will use a SimpleDragSource to initiate drags
member.remarks: Setting this replaces any previous DragSource

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.Items
member.summary: Hide the Items collection so it's not visible in the Properties grid.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ItemRenderer
member.summary: This renderer draws the items when in the list is in non-details view. In details view, the renderers for the individuals columns are responsible.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.LastSortColumn
member.summary: Which column did we last sort by
member.remarks: This is an alias for PrimarySortColumn

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.LastSortOrder
member.summary: Which direction did we last sort
member.remarks: This is an alias for PrimarySortOrder

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ListFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter that is applied to our whole list of objects.
member.remarks: The list is updated immediately to reflect this filter.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ModelFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter that is applied to each model objects in the list

remarks.para: You may want to consider using instead of this property, since AdditionalFilter combines with column filtering at runtime. Setting this property simply replaces any column filter the user may have given.
The list is updated immediately to reflect this filter.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.MouseMoveHitTest
member.summary: Gets the hit test info last time the mouse was moved.
member.remarks: Useful for hot item processing.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.OLVGroups
member.summary: Gets or sets the list of groups shown by the listview.
member.remarks: This property does not work like the .NET Groups property. It should be treated as a read-only property. Changes made to the list are NOT reflected in the ListView itself -- it is pointless to add or remove groups to/from this list. Such modifications will do nothing. To do such things, you must listen for BeforeCreatingGroups or AboutToCreateGroups events, and change the list of groups in those events.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.OwnerDrawnHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user wants to owner draw the header control themselves. If this is false (the default), ObjectListView will use custom drawing to render the header, if needed.
member.remarks: If you listen for the DrawColumnHeader event, you need to set this to true, otherwise your event handler will not be called.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.Objects
member.summary: Get/set the collection of objects that this list will show

remarks.para: The contents of the control will be updated immediately after setting this property.

This method preserves selection, if possible. Use if you do not want to preserve the selection. Preserving selection is the slowest part of this code and performance is O(n) where n is the number of selected rows.
This method is not thread safe.
The property DOES work on virtual lists: setting is problem-free, but if you try to get it and the list has 10 million objects, it may take some time to return.
This collection is unfiltered. Use to access just those objects that survive any installed filters.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ObjectsForClustering
member.summary: Gets the collection of objects that will be considered when creating clusters (which are used to generate Excel-like column filters)

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.OverlayImage
member.summary: Gets or sets the image that will be drawn over the top of the ListView

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.OverlayText
member.summary: Gets or sets the text that will be drawn over the top of the ListView

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.OverlayTransparency
member.summary: Gets or sets the transparency of all the overlays. 0 is completely transparent, 255 is completely opaque.
member.remarks: This is obsolete. Use Transparency on each overlay.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.Overlays
member.summary: Gets the list of overlays that will be drawn on top of the ListView
member.remarks: You can add new overlays and remove overlays that you have added, but don't mess with the overlays that you didn't create.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.PersistentCheckBoxes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not primary checkboxes will persistent their values across list rebuild and filtering operations.

remarks.para: If you use CheckStateGetter/Putter, the checkedness of a row will already be persisted by those methods. This property is only useful when you don't explicitly set CheckStateGetter/Putter.
This defaults to true for virtual lists (Fast, Tree). If you set it to false on virtual lists, you have to install CheckStateGetter/Putters.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CheckStateMap
member.summary: Gets or sets a dictionary that remembers the check state of model objects
member.remarks: This is used when PersistentCheckBoxes is true and for virtual lists.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.PrimarySortColumn
member.summary: Which column did we last sort by

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.PrimarySortOrder
member.summary: Which direction did we last sort

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.RenderNonEditableCheckboxesAsDisabled
member.summary: Gets or sets if non-editable checkboxes are drawn as disabled.

remarks.para: This only has effect in owner drawn mode.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.RowHeight
member.summary: Specify the height of each row in the control in pixels.

remarks.para: The row height in a listview is normally determined by the font size and the small image list size. This setting allows that calculation to be overridden (within reason: you still cannot set the line height to be less than the line height of the font used in the control).
Setting it to -1 means use the normal calculation method.
This feature is experiemental! Strange things may happen to your program, your spouse or your pet if you use it.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.RowHeightEffective
member.summary: How many pixels high is each row?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.RowsPerPage
member.summary: How many rows appear on each page of this control

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SecondarySortColumn
member.summary: Get/set the column that will be used to resolve comparisons that are equal when sorting.
member.remarks: There is no user interface for this setting. It must be set programmatically.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SecondarySortOrder
member.summary: When the SecondarySortColumn is used, in what order will it compare results?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectAllOnControlA
member.summary: Gets or sets if all rows should be selected when the user presses Ctrl-A

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectColumnsOnRightClick
member.summary: When the user right clicks on the column headers, should a menu be presented which will allow them to choose which columns will be shown in the view?
member.remarks: This is just a compatibility wrapper for the SelectColumnsOnRightClickBehaviour property.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectColumnsOnRightClickBehaviour
member.summary: Gets or sets how the user will be able to select columns when the header is right clicked

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectColumnsMenuStaysOpen
member.summary: When the column select menu is open, should it stay open after an item is selected? Staying open allows the user to turn more than one column on or off at a time.
member.remarks: This only works when SelectColumnsOnRightClickBehaviour is set to InlineMenu. It has no effect when the behaviour is set to SubMenu.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectedColumn
member.summary: Gets or sets the column that is drawn with a slight tint.

remarks.para: If TintSortColumn is true, the sort column will automatically be made the selected column.
The colour of the tint is controlled by SelectedColumnTint.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectedRowDecoration
member.summary: Gets or sets the decoration that will be drawn on all selected rows

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectedColumnTint
member.summary: What color should be used to tint the selected column?
member.remarks: The tint color must be alpha-blendable, so if the given color is solid (i.e. alpha = 255), it will be changed to have a reasonable alpha value.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectedIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the index of the row that is currently selected. When getting the index, if no row is selected,or more than one is selected, return -1.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectedItem
member.summary: Gets or sets the ListViewItem that is currently selected . If no row is selected, or more than one is selected, return null.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectedObject
member.summary: Gets the model object from the currently selected row, if there is only one row selected. If no row is selected, or more than one is selected, returns null. When setting, this will select the row that is displaying the given model object and focus on it. All other rows are deselected.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SelectedObjects
member.summary: Get the model objects from the currently selected rows. If no row is selected, the returned List will be empty. When setting this value, select the rows that is displaying the given model objects. All other rows are deselected.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowCommandMenuOnRightClick
member.summary: When the user right clicks on the column headers, should a menu be presented which will allow them to choose common tasks to perform on the listview?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowFilterMenuOnRightClick
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this ObjectListView will show Excel like filtering menus when the header control is right clicked

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowGroups
member.summary: Should this list show its items in groups?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowSortIndicators
member.summary: Should the list view show a bitmap in the column header to show the sort direction?
member.remarks: The only reason for not wanting to have sort indicators is that, on pre-XP versions of Windows, having sort indicators required the ListView to have a small image list, and as soon as you give a ListView a SmallImageList, the text of column 0 is bumped 16 pixels to the right, even if you never used an image.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowImagesOnSubItems
member.summary: Should the list view show images on subitems?

remarks.para: Virtual lists have to be owner drawn in order to show images on subitems

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowItemCountOnGroups
member.summary: This property controls whether group labels will be suffixed with a count of items.
member.remarks: The format of the suffix is controlled by GroupWithItemCountFormat/GroupWithItemCountSingularFormat properties

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowHeaderInAllViews
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the control will show column headers in all views (true), or only in Details view (false)

remarks.para: This property is not working correctly. JPP 2010/04/06. It works fine if it is set before the control is created. But if it turned off once the control is created, the control loses its checkboxes (weird!)

To changed this setting after the control is created, things are complicated. If it is off and we want it on, we have to change the View and the header will appear. If it is currently on and we want to turn it off, we have to both change the view AND recreate the handle. Recreating the handle is a problem since it makes our checkbox style disappear.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SmallImageList
member.summary: Override the SmallImageList property so we can correctly shadow its operations.

remarks.para: If you use the RowHeight property to specify the row height, the SmallImageList must be fully initialised before setting/changing the RowHeight. If you add new images to the image list after setting the RowHeight, you must assign the imagelist to the control again. Something as simple as this will work: listView1.SmallImageList = listView1.SmallImageList;

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SmallImageSize
member.summary: Return the size of the images in the small image list or a reasonable default

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SortGroupItemsByPrimaryColumn
member.summary: When the listview is grouped, should the items be sorted by the primary column? If this is false, the items will be sorted by the same column as they are grouped.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SpaceBetweenGroups
member.summary: When the listview is grouped, how many pixels should exist between the end of one group and the beginning of the next?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.TintSortColumn
member.summary: Should the sort column show a slight tinge?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.TriStateCheckBoxes
member.summary: Should each row have a tri-state checkbox?
member.remarks: If this is true, the user can choose the third state (normally Indeterminate). Otherwise, user clicks alternate between checked and unchecked. CheckStateGetter can still return Indeterminate when this setting is false.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.TopItemIndex
member.summary: Get or set the index of the top item of this listview

remarks.para: This property only works when the listview is in Details view and not showing groups.
The reason that it does not work when showing groups is that, when groups are enabled, the Windows msg LVM_GETTOPINDEX always returns 0, regardless of the scroll position.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UpdateSpaceFillingColumnsWhenDraggingColumnDivider
member.summary: When resizing a column by dragging its divider, should any space filling columns be resized at each mouse move? If this is false, the filling columns will be updated when the mouse is released.

remarks.para: If you have a space filling column is in the left of the column that is being resized, this will look odd: the right edge of the column will be dragged, but its left edge will move since the space filling column is shrinking.
This is logical behaviour -- it just looks wrong.
Given the above behavior is probably best to turn this property off if your space filling columns aren't the right-most columns.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UnfocusedHighlightBackgroundColor
member.summary: What color should be used for the background of selected rows when the control doesn't have the focus?
member.remarks: Windows does not give the option of changing the selection background. So the control has to be owner drawn to see the result of this setting. Setting UseCustomSelectionColors = true will do this for you.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UnfocusedHighlightBackgroundColorOrDefault
member.summary: Return the color should be used for the background of selected rows when the control doesn't have the focus or a reasonable default

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UnfocusedHighlightForegroundColor
member.summary: What color should be used for the foreground of selected rows when the control doesn't have the focus?
member.remarks: Windows does not give the option of changing the selection foreground (text color). So the control has to be owner drawn to see the result of this setting. Setting UseCustomSelectionColors = true will do this for you.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UnfocusedHighlightForegroundColorOrDefault
member.summary: Return the color should be used for the foreground of selected rows when the control doesn't have the focus or a reasonable default

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseAlternatingBackColors
member.summary: Should the list give a different background color to every second row?

remarks.para: The color of the alternate rows is given by AlternateRowBackColor.
There is a "feature" in .NET for listviews in non-full-row-select mode, where selected rows are not drawn with their correct background color.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseCellFormatEvents
member.summary: Should FormatCell events be called for each cell in the control?

remarks.para: In many situations, no cell level formatting is performed. ObjectListView can run somewhat faster if it does not trigger a format cell event for every cell unless it is required. So, by default, it does not raise an event for each cell.
ObjectListView *does* raise a FormatRow event every time a row is rebuilt. Individual rows can decide whether to raise FormatCell events for every cell in row.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseCustomSelectionColors
member.summary: Should the selected row be drawn with non-standard foreground and background colors?
member.remarks: When this is enabled, the control becomes owner drawn.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseExplorerTheme
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this ObjectListView will use the same hot item and selection mechanism that Vista Explorer does.
member.remarks:
This property has many imperfections:
This only works on Vista and later
It does nothing for owner drawn lists. Owner drawn lists are (naturally) controlled by their renderers.
It does not work well with AlternateRowBackColors.
It does not play well with HotItemStyles.
It looks a little bit silly is FullRowSelect is false. But if you absolutely have to look like Vista, this is your property. Do not complain if settings this messes up other things.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseFiltering
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the list should enable filtering

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseFilterIndicator
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the list should put an indicator into a column's header to show that it is filtering on that column
member.remarks: If you set this to true, HeaderUsesThemes is automatically set to false, since we can only draw a filter indicator when not using a themed header.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseHotItem
member.summary: Should the item under the cursor be formatted in a special way?

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseHyperlinks
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this listview should show hyperlinks in the cells.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseOverlays
member.summary: Should this control show overlays
member.remarks: Overlays are enabled by default and would only need to be disabled if they were causing problems in your development environment.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseSubItemCheckBoxes
member.summary: Should this control be configured to show check boxes on subitems?
member.remarks: If this is set to True, the control will be given a SmallImageList if it doesn't already have one. Also, if it is a virtual list, it will be set to owner drawn, since virtual lists can't draw check boxes without being owner drawn.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseTranslucentSelection
member.summary: Gets or sets if the ObjectListView will use a translucent selection mechanism like Vista.

remarks.para: Unlike UseExplorerTheme, this Vista-like scheme works on XP and for both owner and non-owner drawn lists.
This will replace any SelectedRowDecoration that has been installed.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseTranslucentHotItem
member.summary: Gets or sets if the ObjectListView will use a translucent hot row highlighting mechanism like Vista.
member.remarks: Setting this will replace any HotItemStyle that has been

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.View
member.summary: Get/set the style of view that this listview is using
member.remarks: Switching to tile or details view installs the columns appropriate to that view. Confusingly, in tile view, every column is shown as a row of information.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.BooleanCheckStateGetter
member.summary: This delegate fetches the checkedness of an object as a boolean only.
member.remarks:
Use this if you never want to worry about the Indeterminate state (which is fairly common).
This is a convenience wrapper around the CheckStateGetter property.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.BooleanCheckStatePutter
member.summary: This delegate sets the checkedness of an object as a boolean only. It must return true or false indicating if the object was checked or not.
member.remarks:
Use this if you never want to worry about the Indeterminate state (which is fairly common).
This is a convenience wrapper around the CheckStatePutter property.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CanShowGroups
member.summary: Gets whether or not this listview is capabale of showing groups

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CanUseApplicationIdle
member.summary: Gets or sets whether ObjectListView can rely on Application.Idle events being raised.
member.remarks: In some host environments (e.g. when running as an extension within VisualStudio and possibly Office), Application.Idle events are never raised. Set this to false when Idle events will not be raised, and ObjectListView will raise those events itself.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CellToolTipGetter
member.summary: This delegate is called when the list wants to show a tooltip for a particular cell. The delegate should return the text to display, or null to use the default behavior (which is to show the full text of truncated cell values).
member.remarks: Displaying the full text of truncated cell values only work for FullRowSelect listviews. This is MS's behavior, not mine. Don't complain to me :)

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CheckedAspectName
member.summary: The name of the property (or field) that holds whether or not a model is checked.

remarks.para: The property be modifiable. It must have a return type of bool (or of bool? if TriStateCheckBoxes is true).

Setting this property replaces any CheckStateGetter or CheckStatePutter that have been installed. Conversely, later setting the CheckStateGetter or CheckStatePutter properties will take precedence over the behavior of this property.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CheckStateGetter
member.summary: This delegate will be called whenever the ObjectListView needs to know the check state of the row associated with a given model object.

remarks.para: .NET has no support for indeterminate values, but as of v2.0, this class allows indeterminate values.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CheckStatePutter
member.summary: This delegate will be called whenever the user tries to change the check state of a row. The delegate should return the state that was actually set, which may be different to the state given.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.CustomSorter
member.summary: This delegate can be used to sort the table in a custom fasion.

remarks.para: The delegate must install a ListViewItemSorter on the ObjectListView. Installing the ItemSorter does the actual work of sorting the ListViewItems. See ColumnComparer in the code for an example of what an ItemSorter has to do.
Do not install a CustomSorter on a VirtualObjectListView. Override the SortObjects() method of the IVirtualListDataSource instead.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.HeaderToolTipGetter
member.summary: This delegate is called when the list wants to show a tooltip for a particular header. The delegate should return the text to display, or null to use the default behavior (which is to not show any tooltip).
member.remarks: Installing a HeaderToolTipGetter takes precedence over any text in OLVColumn.ToolTipText.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.RowFormatter
member.summary: This delegate can be used to format a OLVListItem before it is added to the control.

remarks.para: The model object for the row can be found through the RowObject property of the OLVListItem object.

All subitems normally have the same style as list item, so setting the forecolor on one subitem changes the forecolor of all subitems. To allow subitems to have different attributes, do this: myListViewItem.UseItemStyleForSubItems = false;.

If UseAlternatingBackColors is true, the backcolor of the listitem will be calculated by the control and cannot be controlled by the RowFormatter delegate. In general, trying to use a RowFormatter when UseAlternatingBackColors is true does not work well.

As it says in the summary, this is called before the item is added to the control. Many properties of the OLVListItem itself are not available at that point, including: Index, Selected, Focused, Bounds, Checked, DisplayIndex.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.LowLevelScrollPosition
member.summary: Return a point that represents the current horizontal and vertical scroll positions

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseNotifyPropertyChanged
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not ObjectListView should subscribe to INotifyPropertyChanged events on the model objects that it is given.

remarks.para: This should be set before calling SetObjects(). If you set this to false, ObjectListView will unsubscribe to all current model objects.

If you set this to true on a virtual list, the ObjectListView will walk all the objects in the list trying to subscribe to change notifications. If you have 10,000,000 items in your virtual list, this may take some time.

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.MenuLabelSortAscending
member.summary: Gets or set the text to be used for the sorting ascending command

member.name: P:BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.Frozen
member.summary: Get or set whether or not the listview is frozen. When the listview is frozen, it will not update itself.

remarks.para: The Frozen property is similar to the methods Freeze()/Unfreeze() except that setting Frozen property to false immediately unfreezes the control regardless of the number of Freeze() calls outstanding.

member.example: objectListView1.Frozen = false; // unfreeze the control now!
